oai_dc:dc.dc:title: List of articles lost or destroyed in the public service
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; United States -- Army -- Quartermaster Corps; Quartermasters; Nashville (Tenn.); United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Equipment and supplies
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This monthly accounting document submitted by Assistant Quartermaster Captain William Alonzo Wainwright details lost and destroyed articles from the quartermaster's stores. This one-page Quartermaster's Department form, designated No. 43, Abstract L, is a printed form with handwritten entries and conveys article, quantity, and circumstances and cause of loss. The circumstances column reports the involvement of a Board of Survey in the resolution of this loss.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States -- Army -- Quartermaster's Dept.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Record Group 21, Adjutant General's Office Records, 1796-1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Boards of survey were convened in cases of destruction or loss of public property. The commanding officer usually called together a group of three officers to evaluate the property, determine the extent of the loss, and assign responsibility for the loss. The appointment of an inspector would follow, with that inspector assessing value and ruling on the property's condemnation or disposal.
